channel.title: CSIS — Analysis (custom RSS)
channel.description: Auto-generated RSS feed for CSIS Analysis pages.

item.title: What’s Next for AGOA?
item.description: The African Growth and Opportunity Act, the flagship U.S. trade agreement with Africa, has expired. As Washington debates the bill’s future, its uneven track record offers lessons on how to effectively strengthen U.S.-Africa commercial engagement moving forward.

item.title: Who Controls the Wrench: The Debate Over the “Right to Repair”
item.description: It is often a challenge for the government to repair its own equipment because it lacks access to the intellectual property necessary for sustainment. But there are pros and cons to the government having the right to repair.

item.title: MBS in Washington: What’s Next for U.S.–Saudi Relations?
item.description: CSIS experts Mona Yacoubian and Michael Ratney, the former U.S. ambassador to Saudi Arabia, unpack Mohammed bin Salman’s upcoming visit to Washington and what it means for U.S.-Saudi relations moving forward.

item.title: Chinese Buoys at Scarborough Shoal
item.description: Collecting data... or sending a message?

item.title: Russia’s Latest Nuclear Saber-Rattling: Nuclear Testing?
item.description: President Putin’s instruction for Russian military and political leaders to begin “preparations for nuclear weapons tests” follows President Trump’s similar order last week, but also fits a wider pattern of nuclear saber-rattling tied to the ongoing war in Ukraine.

item.title: What to Expect from Secretary Hegseth’s November 7 Speech on the Arsenal of Freedom
item.description: Secretary Hegseth’s upcoming “Arsenal of Freedom” address signals a possible historic shift in U.S. defense acquisition and the industrial base—aimed at undoing decades of consolidation, revitalizing industrial capacity, and reforming how the Pentagon delivers capabilities to the warfighter.

item.title: States Weekly: November 5, 2025
item.description: This edition of States Weekly covers November 5, 2025.

item.title: When Thought Becomes Data: The MIND Act and the Coming Debate Over Neurotechnology
item.description: As neurotechnologies advance from medical tools to consumer devices, the question of who controls neural data is becoming urgent. The proposed MIND Act represents Congress’s first attempt to regulate this emerging domain, raising complex questions about privacy, innovation, and national security.

item.title: Leveraging Latin America’s Embrace of the United States
item.description: Americas Program Senior Associate Evan Ellis argues that the widespread U.S.-friendly disposition of Latin America and the Caribbean creates unique opportunities for the United States in economic, security and other domains.
